												This is actually not a bad game.  It's much better than the predecessor 'X-Blades' which isn't even worth your time.  That's not to say it doesn't have flaws, but overall I had fun with it, and it kept my interest long enough to play through it twice.Gameplay is pretty standard hack n slash fare, with two attack buttons and a variety of magical skills you can use fluidly along with your swords.  You also carry a gun you can whip out at any time if you like, and while the third-person shooting may not be as advanced as something like Gears of War, it works and it's easy to use.  There's also an interesting time control mechanic where you can rewind time and fight alongside past versions of yourself.  You'll also use this ability to solve puzzles, although none of them are terribly difficult.There isn't a lot of variety in the enemies, but mowing down hordes of them is still good for some mindless action, and when they do change it up you'll have to adapt your approach accordingly.The visuals are gorgeous in this game.  The sound design is excellent as well.  The characters however, are kind of shallow (the main character in particular is really annoying), and the story is pretty difficult to follow.  These things aren't the main focus of the game though: the gameplay is.  And the gameplay that is there is solid, and there are many unique game environments to make your way through.  All things considered, this is a pretty decent game.

												This turned out to be a pretty fun action game, though it took a while to get going and I didn't like it as much as, say, Marlow Briggs.Ayumi has, unfortunately, only one basic melee attack that you just keep spamming to work up your "rage meter", which then lets you fire off spells. There's also a Dash move for dodging and closing the distance, and you can switch to a ranged weapon which significantly slows you down and makes you unable to Dash. Once an enemy is at low health, you have the option to perform a finishing move - or just keep wailing on them until they go down. There is also "kick" to break blocks that you rarely need to use. All in all, it's pretty uninspiring until you get enough spells to spice up the combat, and really start using the Rewind Time ability.Rewind Time is actually pretty interesting - it rewinds the world around you, while leaving your character alone. Your character's position and any damage you've taken still stays, so you can't "undo" fatal mistakes like you could in the Prince of Persia games.  Rewinding Time creates a "time clone" of you, that then proceeds to go through all the actions you've taken during those "rewound" seconds. So you could unload half a rifle clip at a charging enemy, rewind time as they get close, and then continue shooting. Their health will be back to where it was at the beginning, but they'll start taking double damage because there will now be two of you shooting! This is actually required for some enemies who are surrounded by magical force fields that can only be broken by extremely concentrated hails of bullets.  Rewind Time is also used for some basic puzzles, such as when multiple pressure plates/switches must be triggered at the same timeMost bosses require some strategy to defeat, but it's usually not hard to figure out, and serves as a nice change of pace.You start with the double-jump, which is always appreciated.  As you proceed in the plot, you unlock new spells & abilities, find new equipment (a magical compass pointing the direction of any nearby equipment chest is very useful), and demolish boatloads of enemies. TL;DR - Fun game once you get enough spells/abilities to make the combat less boring, just don't expect something on the level of Devil May Cry, God of War, or even Marlow Briggs.

Alright! Time for another review.So I've been playing Blades of Time, and as an Hack'n'Slash lover, this game surprised me.This is a very addictive game, not because of its story, or voice acting, its puzzles, or anything in particular, but when you start playing it just keeps you glued to it, for short to medium periods of time, but you always need to come back for more. This is only until you finish the main storyline.So, what does the game do well and not so well? Here's a list for you:Pros: Fun fighting, quick and rather easy to pulloff combos* (see in Cons); Weapons (such as rifles and cannons) for long range engagements; Very distinct areas, a wide variety of sights to amuse yourself and fight your way through; Decent and somewhat interesting bossfights; Hidden chests and rewards spread all over the world as you go through the levels, be on the lookout for those as they hold new equipment* (see in Cons) Rather interesting main character (Ayumi), as time goes on you start to develop more interest in her intentions and motivation to go on.Cons: Not the best special abilities, since they're all the same, but with different side effects (burning, or freezing your enemies, etc.) Some frustrating fights (arenas and/or mini boss fights); Not the best graphical fidelity, but has its good moments; A lot of the enemy characters look the same and dress the same; Weak voice acting, at least in English tongue (in Japanese seems to be better) The rewards you get from hidden chests or bossfights, only have a different stat (e.g. you can have a pair of swords that Increases fire damage and another pair that has a different model but instead gives you Freezes enemies for a longer period), the same goes for rings, amulets, but it's slightly more in-depth when it comes to weapons though; Some of the puzzles might be frustrating to finish and some you might even have to take a wild guess in order to proceed to the next area, as sometimes you have no clue or explanation on what to do.Extras:Despite the longer Cons list, I really enjoyed this game.I didn't mention the storyline above, because it's up to you to love it or hate it. I didn't find it amazing, but it's not bad either if you like the gameplay, you'll go along with the story too. Also, the storyline might last you around 8 hours depending on how many secrets you find and the difficulty you play on.The puzzles are decent, and there are a few of them here and there. Not great, not bad, some are quick and some are frustrating.The multiplayer looks interesting, but it's not working (or at least there isn't anyone playing). It's a shame truthfully, looks really fun and somewhat innovative imho.If you happen to catch this game on sale or in a bundle, grab it if you can!And that's it, if you like Hack'n'Slash games, you'll like this one, it's no Devil May Cry, but it's decent enough to give it a go. After all, you're playing this to kill everything around you, right?

												Wow!!! Even by 2012 I thought it was impossible to innovate a hack and slash adventure game. I love the genre, but I just like the colors and combo strategy, I thought God of War covered the good stuff. And then I found this. Another lost gem that faded into non-existence because it's not a major AAA developer. Let me explain myself...The best part about this is the time warp system. This is TOO FREAKING COOL! I'd suggest buying this game JUST to experience this mechanic. It's difficult to be innovative in modern gaming, so it's possible it had been done before and I just missed it, but either way it is incredibly fun. Basically you can reverse time in fairly short increments, but your "past avatar" will still exist doing what you just did while your "present  avatar" is free to do whatever. You can make several of these avatars at once to fight alongside you or help you solve puzzles. It's a bit confusing at first, but once you get the hang of it you can't wait to use it again. How it works is say you have a group of 3 enemies. You can take out your gun and blast away for 5 seconds at one of them while they charge you. Reverse 6 seconds. Your past avatar will now be there shooting at that same enemy. So now you have a few choices. You can use your present avatar to keep shooting at the same enemy, reverse time 6ish seconds again, shoot at that enemy, repeat however many times you want, and then suddenly have 5+ people blasting this enemy away in 2 seconds. Or you can use another avatar to shoot a second enemy, making them stumble or holding them back. Now you have 2+ avatars distracting two enemies, so you can charge in with your main avatar using swords and melee on the third. To top it off, after, say, 3 seconds of meleeing that third mob, you can reverse 4ish seconds, and now you'll have both your past and present avatar wailing away at this mob. Repeat however many times you want. You now effectively have 4+ warriors on the battlefield attacking at the same time, and even though the process took place over 20 seconds, once you reverse to the very start of the battle and continue time, all 3 mobs will drop dead in an instant.It's awesome.The next best thing are the puzzles. FINALLY I find another game with unique puzzles that actually make you think without being outrageously difficult just for the sake of being difficult. And it's none of the usual "do this kind of puzzle once then use it a bunch more times." Instead, they draw elements from previous puzzles but add a twist or two to keep it fresh. I still haven't beaten it, but as of now I've encountered 3 different "types" of puzzles and each one has been expanded upon later in the "level" to make it feel new. Well done.The next best thing is the graphics. Graphics are normally the least of my worries and something I'll glance at, appreciate, and move on. But considering the time period and developer, this game is INCREDIBLE! It absolutely stands up to some of today's games but is beautifully optimized. It baffles me how a game from 2012 can look, and more importantly run, 1000% smoother than a game from 2015.Third I'll go with the boss fights. Again, FINALLY a game that has unique bosses that, again, require you to think and stay focused. Not every single one, some are the typical slash away without getting hit, but others do require specific strategies. And hey the strategies aren't always necessary either. You CAN slash away at this boss for an incredibly difficult 20 minutes, but if you learn how to exploit weaknesses, you can take them down in a few attack runs.Next would be the combat. Not the most innovative aspect of the game, but still a tried and true method that is just as fun as it always is. It starts off pretty generic, but once you start unlocking combos it exponentially increases the fun and some are unique enough to make Blades of Time stand out amongst its God of War and Dynasty Warrior peers. And this is where the time warp mechanic comes in. Just like I was saying with the puzzles, it takes an old mechanic and makes it new again. It's also a good balance between simple and difficult. You cannot just stand there and spam left mouse button. You will die. Though you don't necessarily have to be constantly in motion 100% of the time either...in a good way. You CAN be and it makes it that much more fun, but it isn't completely necessary, which I prefer. I like to jump around a bit and get in hits here and there, then wail away at a single enemy, then jump around a bit more.However I'll finish off with the voice acting and story. To be fair I actually do enjoy the storyline. Maybe it's not pulitzer prize winning, but it is somewhat unique compared to most fantasy games. Unfortunately, as others have noted, the voice acting is horrendous. I actually laugh pretty much any time anyone says anything because it feels so...fake and out of place. You can tell this is where they cut the budget from. If you've ever played an Oblivion or Skyrim mod where the creator did their own voice acting...it's kind of like that. Just awkward with mediocre writing where it's almost difficult to actually pay attention to what they're saying and not how they're saying it.But overall I recommend this game to anyone who likes action games, and DEFINITELY anyone who loves hack and slash games. I am actually quite stingy with prices, so t's difficult to say if it's worth $25. I almost NEVER spend more than $15 on a game. Though $25 on Steam for a 4 year old game is somewhat of a testament to the game's quality. However if it's on sale under $15 I wouldn't even hesitate to add it to your cart. If that extra $10 isn't a big deal to your wallet, then yeah I'll definitely give the go ahead for $25.Blades of Steel 8/10 would do time warp againAnd if you're wondering, I actually got it in one of those "10 Premium Steam Keys" for $1.12 at a certain third party retailer site. I gotta say I got some pretty good games in those bundles, I'd say it's worth getting 1 or 2 if you're looking for something new to try.

												This game is overlooked. Imagine Shadow Of Mordor but without an open world element. Now imagine an interesting story line with some voice acting that does its best to make fun of the main characters hair color. The game play definitely nails it on this one.You start off as an adventurer going to Dragon Land in search of treasure. Obviously things aren't as they seem and you run into foes of all sorts. One's that stalk in the shadows to big bosses that will have you dashing, sort of flying, and dodging every which way. The game does a good job mixing up enemies and tries not to bombard the player with boring old schemes. The game is sort of like Too Human where you fight multiple enemies and can attack them with varying sequences. X is the button to attack with your swords while pushing in the right thumb stick will equip your gun (which can be modified or changed as the game progresses given you are picking up the treasures along the way). This is where it get's interesting though : along the way altars are available that give you certain abilities that you are able to choose from (such as using fire, ice, or a slide attack technique). For instance, if there is a lot of enemies you can press B then X to unleash a fire attack. To do these special attacks however your character needs enough "rage" to be built. This is done by attacking enemies. With rage other special attacks are available or you may choose to heal yourself. The diversity in the attacks hasn't put me to boredom yet. Right button when a player is injured enough will put the player into an animation (some sort of decapitation involving the foe). This is the best part though and why the game is called Blades of Time... within the game by pressing left button the player is able to rewind time and rewind themselves and their foes. Yes, you rewind your player but your player is immobile and doesn't move as time is rewound. This means that even though you attacked one foe already, you can rewind time, then play it forward again and have two of your characters (of one you control) attack the enemy. This process can be repeated sort of by will after it's learned. Heck if you want you can keep rewinding and have one of your characters attack him with blades, one with a gun, one with specials etc... it is possible. The game's difficulty is also at an appropriate level. The visuals are appealing (very appealing I'd imagine for single guys) and screen format is available in 1980X1080 settings. Graphics are not the greatest thing in the world but will not get in the way of game play.Sounds are alright. The voice acting makes the main character seem like a ditz though in some of the things that she says. I have no problem with it, I'm not sure if the devs were going for that but that's what it feels like to me. I'd listen to a bit of the dialogue and have to ask myself "did she honestly just say that"? The gameplay by far though is the best thing about this game. How they managed to use time as a weapon was cool especially allowing the player to deal extra damage to difficult opponents. I got this game in a humble bundle and unless it REALLY REALLY appeals to you I suggest buying it at full price, either than that maybe wait for a sale. RATING : 7.15/10Gameplay B- Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability C Overall  C+

Unfortunately, there is little online competition despite some enthusiasm in the Steam forum.  There is, however, a single player mode where most of the same awards can be earned.  If my review sounds too vague, it's because I've been playing short sessions of this for so long I've forgotten the subtleties of the campaign.Dumb story aside, Blades of Time's real cardinal sin is the placement of checkpoints before cutscenes instead of after.  There's a button to skip through them, but it's still annoying after a dozen deaths in a boss fight.I wouldn't bother getting the Dismal Swamp DLC on its own.  The included mission removes character abilities in favor of allies to protect.  An Outbreak map might also be included, but if that's what you're after then you might as well get the Limited Edition for the Sky Islands one as well.

												Blades of Time is a classic slasher game similar to Prince of Persia series in many ways, utilizing but not coping mostly all of its features - intriguing plotline, acrobatic tricks, dynamic battles with lots of unique enemies, possibility to reverse time to solve puzzles or to defeat mob hoards and tough bosses.Game has quite predictable but decent storyline, beautiful locations and good overall graphics as well as proper animations for characters and ambient, lots of gameplay features, such as combos, guns and magic, simple RPG elements with possibility to use different gear with unique properties, long enough campaign and interesting ‘Outbreak mode’ featuring dota-like gameplay but in the third person mode.Fighting system much easier to learn and use then in other games, you don’t really need to focus on combos and ‘perfect’ attacks, missing few hits wont make current battle much harder or even impassable, but that doesn’t mean you can simply click whole game away. Each enemy need own strategy to deal with and bosses usually requires active usage of time rewind, temporal clones and lots of shooting, especially on hard difficulty.Of cause Blades of Time fighting system not that advanced like in Castlevania or DMC but as for me its still much more enjoyable because it wont enrage you or cheaply delay progress every time you meet harder enemies. Moreover, local magic skills may be used nearly every second without boring grind of energy\mana like in other games, thus making whole gameplay colorful and entertaining when you really enjoy slicing’n’dicing enemies differently.That’s why its quite weird to read negative reviews on game blaming its softcore battle system or non-AAA storyline. Just compare pricetags for Blades of Time and Castlevania for example (10€ and 30€ respectively) and titles itself after what ask yourself what did you expected to get for such a small price and from a game company for whom it was basically a debut RPG game.The only real cons of this game is a quite dead multiplayer (still its easy to find people to play with or against via Steam community groups) and no possibility to cooperatively play story campaign, only team-up in Outbreak Mode. Quite sad because its clear that campaign levels and story itself ready to be played in coop mode, maybe game budget was too low or developers just preferred to focus on singleplayer.Still, for a story driven game for just 10€\$ multiplayer looks more like a bonus then a mandatory feature. Thats why Im thumbing up Blade of Times and recommend this game to everybody who like hack’n’slash genre.

Ayumi isn't even the worst offender of this!Shockingly enough, the characters evolved such that I actually *liked* them- each main character received enough characterization to become real, likeable, *people*, rather than the walking videogame cliches they look like (ridiculously musclebound man, ridiculously over sexualized women). This astounded me; I was not expecting to have anything but contempt for the game's seemingly pathetic attempt at story. The main plot, too, evolves into something worthwhile. The biggest problem this game has is probably the fact that the story and characters are overwhelmingly generic for the first half of the game.... but it does metamorphose into something unique towards the end. Well, the characters do; the story is largely generic still but there are several key plot points that separate it from the rest.Unfortunately what did not evolve over time was the combat. As far as I know there are no combos to learn besides the very limited set you start out with. One of the combos brings you up into the air as you swing your sword about wildly, *but there are never ever any enemies that will be in the air with you*. What ends up happening is a lengthy animation of you swinging your sword in the air for 5 seconds while all the enemies wait for you to return to the ground. This happens automatically when you jump and attack- so if you need to jump over to an enemy *quickly* and attack him, unless you're very careful you might accidentally start that useless combo and it will prevent you from doing time sensitive things (there is no way to stop once started). I feel like I missed out on a mechanic or two though- you can lock onto enemies and dash at them, but 90% of the time the game bugs out and the dash is in slow motion and you never even reach the enemy. Then I read something about hanging from enemies in midair and hitting them with your sword. Huh. The most I was ever able to do was slide off them like they were covered in motor oil. You gain the ability to use fire, ice and generic projectiles very early on and then (with one exception) from there on out, all upgrades are minor and passive (for example, you might gain the ability to do more damage by using fire on someone who is frozen. No expanded gameplay, just ways to optimize damage). I started out really loving the combat, but it gets very old very fast. And it's very buggy. The entire game is buggy actually. Luckily you can usually fix everything by reloading the last checkpoint, but if your checkpoint is before a particularly challenging battle, that can be frustrating.Another major problem with this game is there are too many different mechanics. It feels like I'm playing a very long demo of hundreds of different games. Yes, the combat is boring, but constantly changing the rules of the world is not the way to fix that. At one point you gain wings and can fly, and I don't even think it is explained... then you lose your wings shortly after, also unexplained. I found out by jumping off a cliff and falling to my death. At one point you are given a gun which you are required to use; if you kill the enemies without the gun, they keep regenerating indefinitely, and this is *not explained*. It was pretty obvious I had to use the gun to kill them, but I couldn't quite figure out how, and I couldn't proceed by killing them normally. The biggest problem was the stupid jump combo- you had to freeze the enemy with the gun, then drop the gun and hit them before they thawed, except I would always activate that useless combo and never get to them in time.The time rewind itself is also problematic. For example, the ability is not explained at all. You are told that you have it, then you need to figure out how it works, which is a process that will take the rest of the game. But the game arbitrarily changes the way it works and often doesn't even let you use it! How can you learn to use it if it keeps alternating between different rule sets and often isn't even available to use? So far what I *think* happens with the standard set of rules is; any time clones of you will disappear if the main you alters enough variables in the past. So if you go back in time and get an enemy to follow the current you instead of the past you, the past you just disappears. Which is a problem because most of the time the point of time rewind is to distract enemies- but they mostly seem interested in *you*, not your past clones, which makes them all vanish, which makes the game frustrating. OK, so I understand that, I'll try to use it against this boss now that I'm a little better with it. Oh wait, you can't. Why? Because. Time rewind is not available to you for nearly *every single boss*. Then, some of the larger enemies require that you use it, but the way it works is completely different for those enemies. In one case- there's a quick time event which you need to do twice at the same time. Cool right? Not really. You do it once, you rewind time and if you don't press the button *immediately*, you lost your shot at it and you need to spend 5 more minutes weakening the enemy again. To reiterate- you can't just go back in time and wait for the opportunity to use the quick time event going forward in time, you have to hit the quick time event whilst going backwards in time.. because for some reason your clone disappears in this particular context (you can't make time rewind clones). Then, on the giant worm boss, you can make time rewind clones but the moment you do the boss just retreats, changing variables and erasing all your clones immediately. The logistics of this time rewind thing is complicated enough without all the arbitrary exceptions and changes.I can't decide if I like this game or not. On the one hand, there are unique gameplay and story elements that are definitely worth experiencing; there is nothing else like it. On the other hand, the game doesn't respect itself enough to expand upon the more interesting elements and instead chooses to try 100 different things, which all collapse into one incoherent mess of a game. I suppose I recommend this game only because the length is short enough that you can actually complete it before being fed up with its many issues, and I think it is worth at least $10, so pick it up in the next sale.

All we really know is that Ayumi wants to get out of Dragonland (original) preferably with some treasure.  Everyone else just seems to want to kill you and that's all that seem relevant.There is an upgrade system but it's largely unsatisfying.  Your basic skills remain largely the same you mostly just build on your magic.The controls were not prioritized well and many functions just won't work at critical moments.  I almost think that the programmers thought that this should be the central idea for the final boss fight.  The game is challenging but some of the challenges feel like they went the whole wrong way. There is some intense challenges in this game, but sometimes you'll just get stumped on what do, like when you encounter the Slasher on the Skydock.  You'll end up dead and then looking at the screen wondering where you went wrong.  In all, Blades of Time feels like a pretty good game with a REALLY AWESOME game trying to get out.  It mixes combat systems in a really cool way, but doesn't polish them to make them shine.  It gives us a story, but can't be bothered for good presentation. 												This game is one of those hidden gems. It's not perfect but it's similar to playing a game like Soul Reaver, Darksiders, Castlevania or Devil May Cry. You play as Ayumi, a treasure hunter who is looking for the treasure of Dragonland. The only way to get to Dragonland is by using the Sphere owned by the secret Guild. So, Ayumi and her partner, Zero bash into the guild and use the sphere to force teleport to Dragonland. In Dragonland, you meet the Chaos Keeper Statues and the Dragon Spirit of Time and then the story begins.I must say that this game is on the way towards improving itself, I think Gaijin Entertainment (Russian developer) & Konami can probably get better. It's a failed remake of X-blades but worth trying it on sale. ($3.99)There is a major gamebreaking control bug in the last boss. It caused me to be unable to complete the game. Due to its severity, I had to change my vote to vote this game down.PROS1. Gun and Sword style fightingIt's exactly like playing the beat-them-up games.2. Quick To LearnIt's super easy to pick up if you've played other beat-them-up games.3. The TeleporterVery nice design. I like the way you made it spin before teleportation.4. Sunlight is DeadlyI like the idea. Not being able to fight in intense solar radiation.5. SkyguardsNice idea too.6. Different Guns / SwordsNice to know the inventory work differently.7. The Time WarpingAlso cool. Especially when you have to piece together a puzzle to kill a creature. I would have preferred more time powers instead of just rewind. 8. Rocket LauncherA pity that you are forced to drop it whenever you jump. This is most ridiculous.9. ExecutionsLove the way it's quickly executed, even in mid air or mid combat. There is a slight graphics twitch but it's acceptable.10. Aerial CombatI love the way you can dash to an enemy and slash him to bits.11. CreativityFloating corals? Dying Sun planet? Sky Island? Nice.CONS1. Lame NamesDragonland? Blades of Time?2. Exact CopyIt's just way too similar to the other beat them up games.a. Speed Dashb. Dash Grabc. Air Dashd. Range / Melee comboe. Double JumpAt least, improve on them.3. Bad MarketingThe team didn't advertise this game well when it was released.4. Enemies are Carbon CopiesYou will see the same enemy in the same Verne model over and over again. The only difference is the top hat. E.g. The mercenaries.5. No CitiesNo rest stops, no shops, just chop chop chop. No additional nuggets of information and lore.6. Rocket LauncherIt drops when you jump or dash. It's a very silly balance mechanic to prevent you from carrying it over to another location.7. GraphicsPretty mediocre. Honestly, there is nothing interesting to look at.8. Chaos SlasherThat's the Dahaka from Prince of Persia.9. Floating Coral GrabsThey are the same as grabbing lights in Devil May Cry or Darksiders.SUGGESTIONS1. Special Attack StylesLook at Alice (American McGee) for more details on how to design.2. More WeaponsI've played the Darksider series and I think more weapons would increase the variety.3. Flipover / Slide UnderThe Prince of Persia series allows you to flip over an opponent. I think this would be a great addition to the movements Ayumi can do. A slide under in between the legs of an enemy would be great too.4. Flying Gun CombatImagine raining rockets while flying or shooting while in the air like Devil May Cry. That would be pretty cool. 5. Co-op Tower ChallengeI think this could be in the next series. Perhaps, Blades of Time is pretty lame so you could make a new series with all the same mechanics.6. Wall Run / Wall Hop / Wall grab / Wall Combat.The usual.7. Stealth AssasinationsGood to have but not compulsory.8. SwimmingAll that water, a bikini and no swimming? What a waste.9. Complex Puzzles for Big Ticket StuffIf you have a secret chest or a super boss, finding a hidden location or a complex puzzle would be great. For story progression, simple puzzles and locks.

												TL:DR – Third person hack and slash game similar to Darksiders, but very linear. There’s no significant backtracking, and all the puzzles are pretty easy to solve. You can beat the game in less than 10 hours. Technically, it has RPG elements but is extremely simplified.In Blades of Time you play the treasure hunter Ayumi, a scantily clad, double sword wielding fighter who can kill a whole room full of armed men but can still occasionally act like Lara Croft in the Tomb Raider reboot (whiny and afraid). It’s hard to blame her though because after trying to crash her way into a mythical treasure trove, she and her sidekick Zero (a big buff dude) get thrown into Dragonland. Now separated from Zero, you (as Ayumi) need to find your way through the monster infested Dragonland back to your own world. No, Dragonland doesn’t have any dragons for you to fight, but there are a variety of creeps itching to take a bite out of all your exposed skin.Gameplay wise, Blades of Time is a third person melee game where you can just mash the attack button and Ayumi will swing her swords like a ninja commando slashing everyone around her. However, unlike games such as Darksiders or Devil May Cry, the enemies aren’t really “stunned” by your hits and can still attack you even as they’re flinching from your strikes. Your attacks don’t interrupt them.  Fortunately you have a short range dash/dodge move that you can use to evade enemy attacks. One thing I noticed is that either the enemies all have a lot of health or your sword strikes are really weak, because killing enemies takes a lot more hits than you would expect.  Seriously, it takes like 20-30 hits to kill anything with your swords. You do have a rifle to shoot baddies with though, and that seems to be pretty strong.I said before that the game is simplified, and this applies to character development and equipment. You don’t “level up” in the game, and you don’t collect money to buy items with either. As you progress through the story, you “find” new skills or upgrades to your existing ones. They’re unmissable so don’t worry about not finding an awesome spell. All of your equipment upgrades are found using a homing compass that also guides you on which direction you should be traveling. The equipment is missable, but none of it is game changing. They all just boost 1 of your skills, and nothing else (no +armor or +damage). There are only a few magic spells for you to use (fire, ice, and a heavy blast) but they add a little variety to your gameplay. They’re not especially strong either though. Probably your greatest tool (and the reason for the game’s title) is your ability to reverse time for a short period. During the time reversal, enemies and your past self will re-enact what happened a few seconds ago. During this window you can attack the enemy with your clone for a double or even triple attack (if you reverse time in the middle of another time reversal). This is also used for puzzle solving since there are some areas that you can’t progress without hitting 2 switches at the same time (stand on switch 1 and reverse time, then stand on switch 2 while your clone is still on switch 1). Pros:+Simple gameplay and no “research” needed. Don’t worry about character building.+The game runs smoothly despite having nice graphics for a fantasy world with magic and monsters. My computer didn’t even heat up very much.Cons:-If you’re looking for an in-depth RPG like Dragon age, or a loot game like Diablo, Blades of Time isn’t the game for you. Also, the game’s “dialogue” is kind of weird. I don’t know if it’s translated from another language or just badly written at times.-There is this really annoying bug involving getting your spell casting “stuck” that requires a game restart to fix. It happens a lot in boss battles, and at first I didn’t even realize it was a bug. I thought I had a keyboard button jammed or something. It occurs when an enemy interrupts one of your magic spells.-The Outbreak multiplayer option plays like a third person MOBA but there’s nobody playing online. Don’t get this game for the multiplayer.Overall, the game is fun to spend a weekend on, especially if you just want brainless hack and slash without worrying about exploring huge areas or backtracking. You also get to fight large boss monsters and earn some easy Steam achievements. 7/10

												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #25 - Blades of TimeI admit I didn't have very high hopes for this game going in.  Looking at the rather scantily clad heroine Ayumi, it struck me that this game was going to be some kind of lame Tomb Raider wannabe.  I definitely wouldn't have picked up this game on my own, but I got it as part of a Humble Bundle.  The story doesn't exactly get off on a strong start.  I start the game as Ayumi, the aforementioned scantily clad treasure hunter who gets teleported to some place called "Dragon Land".  Along the way Ayumi's partner is lost, so the game pretty much starts with 2 quests, one to find treasure, and one to find your partner.I say quest lightly because this isn't really a role playing game where you have a quest journal and all that.  This is more of an action-adventure game that is fantasy based.  Rather than having a quest journal, Ayumi doubles as the narrator of the story, so you'll constantly hear Ayumi make comments about her situation and surroundings.  Unlike a lot of other reviewers, I actually liked the voice acting here.  Ayumi sounded really familar and I kept trying to figure out where I had heard her before.  I finally had to look it up on IMDB, and it turns out it's the same actress (Miranda Raison) who played Cassandra in Dragon Age: Inquisition.  Even though I liked the voice acting, the story isn't really that memorable.  It felt like the equivalent of watching a movie that just goes from set-piece to set-piece, with just enough story to stitch things together loosely.What this game is really about is the combat, with some occasional puzzles mixed in.  The combat is fast paced with a lot of button mashing.  The fighting reminded me a lot of playing God of War.  Although the fights are fast paced, the enemies start out pretty simple to give you some time to warm up to combat.As you progress, you'll run into altars which are part of the story, but gameplay wise is basically a way of handing out powers over time, so you gradually become more powerful and have time to acclimate to each new set of moves.  At first, your powers are basically just different ways of attacking, but then you start getting the ability to leap around.Things got more interesting right as I was wrapping up my first hour of play, when the game gave me the ability to turn back time.  It's clear this is going to be used as a puzzle solving technique throughout the game.  The effect is pretty neat being able to rewind time to essentially create a clone of yourself who follows your original path while you can replay a section of time to do something different.While I wasn't very invested in the story, the combat was fun and engaging, and the next thing I knew I had beaten my first boss fight, and wrapped up my first hour of play.  My expectations were low going in, but I admit I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun I had.I definitely wouldn't recommend this game to everyone.  Combat is twitchy enough that I think casual players may become frustrated.  Also if you like your adventure games to have more of an emphasis on story, then this is probably not the game for you.  But if you are willing to set these concerns aside and embrace the combat, then your time in Blades of Time will be well spent.

												Blades of Time is a second-tier game, but a good one.  The feel is similar to God of War, but somewhat less epic.  Combat is mostly straightforward - heavy on mashing the LMB, light on complex combo sequences - but the gradual addition of unlockable abilities adds enough tactical options to keep the fights engaging.  The big selling point to Blades of Time is the "Time Rewind" mechanic that allows you to stay in place while rewinding time by a few seconds, allowing you to team up with your past self to defeat difficult enemies or solve puzzles.  It's a minor innovation that pales after a few uses, and I quickly found myself eschewing the mechanic in favour of good old button-mashing mayhem, except when faced with bosses and puzzles that demanded it.Gameplay is very linear; you're pretty-much marched down one continuous corridor from mob fight, to puzzle area, to boss arena and onwards.  That particular sin is typical of this genre, though, and when such games do give you the freedom to revisit past areas (as in Darksiders) it doesn't really add much to the gameplay, anyway.Overall, this is a solid, workmanlike offering.  There have definitely been titles I enjoyed more (the God of War series outstanding among them,) but the failure to achieve excellence shouldn't detract from the fact that this is a very playable package with no serious flaws. And yes, the protagonist is a busty young woman who wears very little clothing.  Apparently this matters.

												Though it has flaws, Blades of Time is no doubt potentially a fun game.  I say "potentially" because if it weren't for the massive framerate drop during the entire game, the repetiive enemies, the uninteresting characters, predictable gameplay, terrible platforming, and the puzzles, I would say this would be a buy instead of a rent.  Despite being "Limited Edition" version, all that is "limited" is an extra level which you play as a different character...which should've been an option from the start.  (Why is it that "Limited Editions" are the "complete package" again?)  The idea of having your avatar go back in time to use your past selves to fight alongside your present version is a great gameplay mechanic, especially when used in the right way such as fighting enemies.  The main problem is, like any other hack-and-slash game, this mechanic is often pushed to the side or being thought of as a secondary option for combat rather than being the focus.  The enemies are repetitive, making the gameplay predictable as you will be forced into implementing the same strategy to defeat the same enemy over and over again, which doesn't add much to the "time" mechanic when you think about it.  The game tries to give you a break from combat to do some puzzles, but they are not very exciting and are WAY too easy to complete (I hate puzzles anyway).  The only challenging level was the desert level where if you touch the hot sand, you will die, forcing you to use the shade as a literal cover.  No other game I know of has a creative level like that!  Also, the characters are so bland, and the main charcter Ayumi NEVER SHUTS UP!  Always with the complaining!  Other M syndrome, anyone?  Finally, the controls are VERY clunky.  The jumping mechanic is especially annoying and tedious because when you jump, you either automatically "bounce" or slide before you come to a complete halt, and it makes the platforming sections all the more frustrating.  This is something MANY modern platforming games whether 2D or 3D shouldn't be doing.  In the end, Blades of Time has the potential to be something more, but in the meantime, I suggest renting this game instead of buying it.

None of the characters were intriguing, and the interaction and introduction of the characters was extremely sloppy.If you can get past all of that, then you have a serviceable beat-em-up. 												Man... If only I was able to describe my feelings about this game more precisely I would. I don't exactly have a black and white opinion about this game, although I do feel that I don't exactly recommend this game. Knowing that this game WAS a budget title it did deliver its value... Sort of. The game is good over-all the combat is pretty fast-paced, the level design was great. Locations deliver that very "fantastical" sort of idea that, that kind of world would only exist in a dream. I haven't gotten that far into the game yet, considering the amound of time I've played before writing this review (about less than an hour). I feel though that I've gotten enough things to cringe about in Blades of Time.One, the animations. Man... I don't exactly understand the whole dynamic as to why this is a problem in the first place but, considering I know just a tad bit about animation, is that every movement takes a TON of time. Walk cycles are the worst when trying to animate by hand, without a mocap device. Anyways, I noticed one big peeve of mine for BoT: Ayumi's running  cycle. If you don't pay much attention to it, it looks decent enough to make a big deal out of it. But, what I notice is that with every step, her head just turns with her body. 95% of the time she's looking left and right and rarely to the front. I see myself already in the future when I play the game and just have those long running sequences I'll just get constantly bothered by the fact that she can't look at one damn direction when she's running. I thought it sort of made sense at first since, she was in a completely new world and she wanted to just take as much of its beauty in as possible. But nope, just a damn animation problem. I don't think it would have taken much to lock her head relatively in the same position as she's moving: forward. It shouldn't take much precision either, as long as it's in approximately the same location the whole time, it should be flawless. Another problem that I have with her running is her arms and legs. She flails her legs outward while keeping her knees in so she sort of pushes her body in a diagonal direction (which may explain why she keeps turning her damn head, although probably not). It's hard to describe for me through text but just look up gameplay and I'm sure you"d understand. Also her arms are kept way too close to her body for her to even look like she's running comfortably. Her arms, instead of moving forward and back while she runs, they more rotate around her body in a sort of elbow-to-chest-then-to-shoulder-blade movement. Ridiculous I know, but I'm not known for being good at describing things.Second, the narrative that Ayumi does. THE CONSTANT NARRATIVE. I swear after every minor part, she's going to speak her mind about either the world or what she thinks about the new enemies she'll encounter. It becomes a bit of an annoyance. Again, I'm still not that far into the game, maybe that'll change but, we'll see. Also the way the game gives you hints about how to progress the level is... I don't know. Compared to other games, the way the hint is either presented or shown, it sort-of makes me feel idiotic. Like, I could have figured that out all by myself? Yet, that's all based on opinion and I don't want to force you to believe me on that point. But let's look at the wider aspect, the voice acting itself. It's pretty good, to say the least. The only problem I'd have is with Ayumi's narration, sometimes it's very noticeable that she's reading off of a script rather than being immersive into the BoT world. I'll update my opinion once I've finished the game.Last, the shooting mechanics. It's too locked for me. Like, I'm moving on an axes instead of fluid mouse motion. Also the way Ayumi moves when in "Gun Mode" is way too smooth. She's basically sliding on the ground rather than walking when she's aiming. I feel like there'd need to be some sort of bobbing motion while you move to at least make the game feel just a tad bit more, normal? I'd say? The movement is too mechanic rather than fluid. But I could also incorporate this with my first point but I'm too lazy to care (heheh..)Overall I'd say this game is playable if you don't pay attention to much of the details in which I've pointed out thus far. It's got a pretty promising story line, fast-paced combat, awesome level, character, and monster design (no it's not because the main character looks attractive, although in my opinion it's sort of wierd to say she is, since... I don't know I guess you'll have to see it for yourself and establish your own decision), pretty good sountrack too! Well yeah, I'd say a 7 out of 10. I got the game off of a bundlestars bundle so if you want to pick the game up? I'd say you'd get your money's worth if you got it through that, and hey, you'll get 7 extra games that you most likely will not play along with it. But for $4.01? I'd say it's worth a shot.

												Must-have game for the Action RPG lover!  The fighting mechanics are some of the best I've seen since Batman: Arkham Asylum and Arkham City.  It VERY smoothly integrates First Person shooting with real-time, in-your-face, combat.  It's quite addicting, actually.  The coolest part of the game, though, is the "Time Rewind" feature.  They integrate this with the combat so flawlessly that it adds SO much possibility to the way you can go about killing monsters!  Basically, you rewind time from the actions you just performed, and you create clones that re-enact what you just did...meanwhile, your real self can do different actions - and then you can rewind time again and have multiple clones doing multiple actions, and it's just a big cycle!  Sometimes, it's necessary to use this feature to kill monsters, too, which is really neat.  It forces you to learn how to use the tool, and I'm glad it did!    The puzzles are also brainbusters - I had to look up tips and hints for a couple of them!

												At present, these are only my first impressions, but I have to say that from what I've seen so far, this game is really quite enjoyable. I'd describe it as a cross between Bayonetta and Tomb Raider - it's a hack-n-slash by nature but it also has a third-person shooter element, and you can switch between these modes on the fly, which I find to be a really interesting addition - it allows for a unique take on both genre's formulas, and contrary to what you might think, in the midst of a fight flicking between the modes feels rather natural - it almost feels as if the game encourages you to use both in tandem to achieve your goal.In hack and slashes of this game's type, combos tend to be both essential and, for a gamer like me, rather hard to pull off. Blades of Time remedies this a little - whereas in a game like Bayonetta the combos would be a ridiculous string of button presses, Blades of Time has relatively simple button combos, press one button to ready, press another to attack. In that sense I found myself enjoyng the game a lot more, because I didn't really need to worry about all the ridiculous combos I'd have to pull off - While a more hardcore hack-n'-slash fan might not find this appealing, I personally think it's a nice touch, making the game easy to jump in and out of without needing pinpoint-precise button presses.I have but two criticisms of this game: First, the english voice acting is pretty bad, though this is remedied by simply switching the voice language to Japanese, and second, the story makes absolutely no sense - the game goes straight from the title screen into the opening cutscene without a shred of explanation as to what is going on. However, when you're in the thick of it, hacking and slashing and shooting and magicking enemies like there's no tomorrow, you honestly forget about these errors, because you're just having too much fun to really care.Overall, despite its shortcomings, Blades of Time is a lot of fun, and an interesting fusion of the hack & slash and third-person shooter genres, and I'd reccommend this game if you were a fan of either genre. An underrated gem, this game has enough action to keep you entertained for a long time.

												Great game. Can easily stand up to genre kings like Devil May Cry. Fast fighting fun in a very pure, uncompromised and likeable way. A solid selection and variety of moves, an interesting time-rewind feature to overwhelm enemies with multiple copies of oneself and solve basic button-press puzzles, nicely designed enemies, varied, beautifully designed and memoreable levels, a great soundtrack, a not necessarily revolutionary but nevertheless somewhat interesting story (it needs time to build up, but when it does it takes pretty epic shapes), increasingly likeable characters, a pretty good voice acting and big numbers of lines. It runs fast and smooth, the controls are easy (I played with an XBOX controller) and I picked it up very cheaply in a bundle. For which I feel like a thief now. I think I'm gonna buy one or another copy for the full price just because it seems that this game is a severly underrated gem.There is even an online versus mode as well as a mildly strategic single- and multiplayer co-op arena tower defense mode with leveling and item mechanics and stuff. In other games I would usually see such a multiplayer mode sceptical, but as the singleplayer portion of this game is already great enough I think this is pretty awesome to have. I played the co-op mode once with a Japanese and it worked (which is not self-evident in such games). I didn't notice severe lags or synchronisation issues despite the distance to the host. We (well, I at least) had a blast. I didn't understand all he said over his mic because I don't speak Japanese, but we ran over tons of monsters and my screen was all slash and boom and peng and pow. A few platforming sections I died in more often than I probably had to because the double-jump from the protagonist is not the most precise. There are some platforming and trap-evading parts where someone else might get a little frustrated, but I got through okay and the checkpoints in this game seem pretty fair.Also, the story and character relationships can be a little confusing. Some good thoughts went into it, that's for sure, there are lore hinches that I liked. In the end everything gets resolved fairly well, but in the middle the game sometimes lost me a bit. I don't know if that is because I didn't play the prequel "X-Blades" (which I sure will too soon). But, as mentioned, it finds a satisfying and understandable end.

												It is hard to write a small review about a game that you are enjoying in some aspects but despising in others. I will keep it as short and simple as possible:Pro:-Gorgeous Environments, for the most part.-An (also for the most part) decent voice acting in all available languages (japanese best tho.)-Large Variety of Enemies with some fresh ideas-Good Animations-Nice Time Rewind Mechanic-Actually fun puzzling-A decent fighting system with awesome magic skills...Con:-...which sadly lacks ANY impact in normal swordfighting (not magic) due to horrible sound effects and just not really good audiovisual feedback. Seriously, for the most part it sounds like you would try to rub cardboard swords against a cardboard enemy. Often you can't tell if your attacks stagger an enemy or if he attacks back.-The controls, while fluid for the most part, just infuriate sometimes. WHY does the character stop after a jump, so you have to wait a second to run on? That just doesn't fit the gameplay. Same with dashing.-Some annoying glitches (rare though. I clipped through the ground twice, which is not gamebreaking but annoying.)-Horrible, horrible...HORRIBLE cutscenes. The characters move and act like paper. The voice acting, like stated in pro, is alright though.-While, like stated in pro, the environments and enemies are often enjoyable and lush, there are WAY too many muddy textures that should just not have been there. It really drags down the otherwise beautiful scenery.In the end it is still recommendable if you can overlook the lacking impact of fighting and some of the above issues. It is still fun, and while you will often shake your head about issues, the game is still...just, fun. Simple fun that the issues won't take away - luckily.Personal Score: 7,5/10

I was wrong, i can admit that.First of all, the game has decent graphics, not awesome, but allright for a mid budget game. I have seen(heard) better voice acting, not game breaking, but it takes some points from the overall score.What is most important for me is the gameplay, which is what it made me decide to uninstall (not that ill never play it, but i will send it way back on the queue in my library). The mechanics are actually almost rock solid, jumps, attacks, everything reacts fine as it should there is almost as solid as God of war except for 1 little detail.when you use your attacks to test them, or against the air, well, you notice that you are hitting air. The problem is that when you hit an enemy or object, or the wall, you feel exactly the same, squat, nada. You cant feel the power behind your blows. You hit an enemy, you see that you are hitting them, yet you dont feel it on your control (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYEebRNb0ag  Minute 20 as an example, when he breaks a crate, then he hits a large enemy 10-15 seconds later). In any hack/slash buttonmash game, when you hit an enemy, there is a proper reaction, either a combo hitcounter, some reaction of pain of the enemy, maybe slower attacks from your part. i dont know, something. In this game you feel like you are slashing leaves every single time,.even the old snes beat em ups got those things right. I could kept playing, the mechanics are solid enough, i could bear the voice acting, couldnt complain about the graphics neither or the frenetic camera (yeah, you can dash and the camera moves a bit violently) , its just that i felt that my mouseclicks were worthless. there is no epicness in this. It felt empty/weak.For better understanding of what i am saying. Imagine you are playing street fighter. You get in CQC, you throw a fierce punch to your enemy in the face, you hitted him, you see his health bar going down, yet there was no proper animation, your fist just went trought his face, yet worse, since you didnt altered his animation he can actually counter, and you will see your character on the ground, less health, but you just never felt a thing.So yes, small detail, game breaker for me. I wouldnt get this game unless it comes in a bundle or if its really cheap, less than 5 USD and i still would doubt it. And thats why i cant recommend the game, otherwise, this could be a little jewel.

To keep this short, I'll just say this: This game, not unlike your average DC movie (OHHHHHHH!!!11) makes for great trailers, but the finished product is better left on the shelf. Because, like a DC Movie (OHHHHHH!!!!111one), everything is kind of okay for a while, and then it starts...SecondbySecondNarration.  *Standing in fire* Oh, there’s fire up in hurr. 												I've only just started playing this and here are my thoughts so far.The game starts off with an awkward cinematic and this is before you even get to the main menu. Like the cinematic looks epic in my opinion, but it makes absolutely no sense. There was an initiation to figure out who goes to Dragonland, then the bad guys the ones who seem bad come in and try to steal the sphere to Dragonland and the good guy just let's them take the sphere and go to Dragonland.I find this weird as it doesn't explain anything as to why they are going to Dragonland, why you play as the people who seem bad in the opening cinematic, why the good guy jus let the evil people have the sphere. It all makes no sense.This may all be explained as I play more, but for now it's all confusing as hell. Which isn't good to make people confused before they even get to the main menu! But now onto my thoughts.The Positive:♦ The scenery and graphics looked pretty cool and unique♦ The Platforming seemed cool♦ I like how everything is read to you♦ I like how the inventory is in the form of a handbook ♦ The unqiueness of the enemies are cool and the number of different ones are awesome♦ I liked the combat style and the gun.♦ I liked the way you get spells ♦ I like how you can press "E" on a nearly dead enemy to do a special and finish them♦ I like the idea of using a compass to find hidden objects and to find the main objectiveThe Negative:♦ The voice of your character was weird and annoying, some of the things she said was obvious beyond belief and unneeded. ♦ Characters Face is messed up graphics wise♦ The story seems to start in the middle... as explained above with the openeing cinematic. It could be a mad story and well written... but it seems to leave major parts out. For example who is Zero, why is he so important, why are we going to Dragonland etc etc. It all just seems to start in the middle. It may explain more as I play... but they needed more backstory (I thought there was a prequel that I missed or something, but nope).♦ It seems Repetitive as. Go here, kill these, learn these, repeat. ♦ I haven't come accross any puzzles yet... if they are supposed to puzzles then well uh, they suck beyond repair. ♦ Whole game seems too easy♦ I dislike the timestop spell, don't get me wrong it's cool as it stops time, but to me it seems like they didn't implement it well to make use of it's coolness. It just seems to be there to make it almost near impossible to kill enemies with it. ♦ Absolutely no challenges♦ I dislike how 90% of the game so far that I've played is go here, kill these enemies, oh look a wall, walk some more, step on a button, kill some more enemies, walk back the way you came and now the wall is open. Repeat. ♦ Dislike the gun having unlimited ammo, this makes it way too easy and unrealistic.♦ Needs to be more weapon types and different guns to make it slightly more interesting♦ Spells are just given to you and are given pretty fast. They say you need to collect souls or something from enemies you destroy to unlock them, but the spells seemed to just be handed to you which is lame. It gives you no incentive to actually want to kill everything.♦ Spells seem pointless and not needed as you can easily kill enemies without them♦ The compass is cool but it's pointless as you can easily find everything without it. It doesn't add to the game anything you couldn't do without. Thus as cool as it is, it is pointless.Glitches:♦ At some points, I lost control to my spells, gun reloading and compass. The only way to fix this was to quit the game and re-open it. Really annoying.On a whole the game in my opinion has awesomeness too it, don't get me wrong. Like the way you get and use spells, can dash to enemies, can find things with a compass, can stop time and the way you fight with meelee is awesome!Although that is all good, it is poorly implemented along with the storyline. TimeStop seems cool until you realize all it does is make you fight enemies for years, spells seems unneeded, the compass doesn't really help (You could find everythign without it) and learning to use spells as cool as it is, seems pointless when they are self explanitory things like fire, freeze, critical strike etc.I'd give it an overall raiting of 2.5/5.

												This is a much better game than []X-Blades[/url]. Both are hack and slash with an exact same character name but what makes Blades of Time special is the time manipulation as the game mechanics. Dodging is floaty and as you use melee with swords it doesn't feel punchy or satisfied hitting the enemies. Execution is somewhat passable, magic attacks use a skull orb on set gauge bar that you can fill the bar with attacks. That limits the number of magical abilities you can use.So far the first boss ignored every range attack and in that area I assume I need to stand on a platform switch to reveal its weak spot. 												Overall, BoT is a pretty decent game.Combat is pretty good, but is made really interesting with this game's eponymous feature: time manipulation.  Essentially, you can do something, such as attack an enemy, and then rewind, and your previous actions will be enacted again by another (short-lived) you, while you can also do something, such as also attacking an enemy. This makes for interesting battles into which you're able to incorporate a good amount of strategy, which helps prevent the monotony of hacking and slashing so much.  However, this power is also poorly utilized, such as with annoying doors which you need to open, but since they then close nearly immediately, you must rewind time and wait for yourself (in the other timeline) to unlock it again and then quickly dash through.If story/dialogue is something you focus on in games, this games' story is confusing and hard to follow, due to the very poor dialogue.  This is exacerbated by trying to make some characters talk in Old English-style (eg: "Thou dost...").  This is very poorly executed, and sounds extremely awkward.  Furthermore, some of the regular dialogue is just silly or sounds weird or unnatural.On a brighter note, the game is relatively well optimized and runs quite well.  The scenery is quite imaginative and often is very beautiful.  I think I've taken more screenshots of this game than all the other games combined.

												"Blades of Time", a 3rd person hack & slash in the manner of "Devil May Cry", is a game where nothing feels quote right.You are a scantily-clad blond treasure hunter named Ayumi (I guess the developers where watching watching/reading too many animes/mangas), who is transported to Dragonland (because magic) where there's untold treasure (because ancient legends), and of course, a warmongering Chaos demon (because ancient prophecy). And you are sort of in the middle of all this, and hack & slash your way through without true reasons.Extremely crappy story aside, there's much wrong with this title.First, the visuals. What seems a lush and vibrant world at first glance, is really just a stiff, brightly-colored jungle. Ayumi just clips through the greenery, the leaves and grass are mostly static. Dragonland felt like a colorful dead world. Character animations are stiff, too. What look like detailed models from afar are revealed to be really mediocre ones. But, this is a budget title, so the graphics issues are truly the least concern.What is a huge issue are the gameplay and the controls.Ayumi moves too fast. She jumps too high. Controlling her never feels alright. Precision jumping is almost impossible. Even walking narrow ledges is a challenge due to speedy movement. The enemies have no "meat". Ayumi's swords just sort of pas through them, and then they eventually fall down. The combo system is poor, and the melee deteriorates into mindless button mashing. The shooting part of combat seems tacked-on and minimally refined.Add to all this the fact you have to constantly bear with Ayumi's babbling, presented via poor and annoying voice-work...Ugh, There's much to quit "Blades of Time", and very little to stick to it.

												Blades of Time is a nice 3rd person action game with some cool mechanics and it looks good to boost. The enviroments are nice and varied, the enemies less so, but fun to fight nonetheless. Fighting is pretty standard, normal attacks, magic attacks, and even 3rd person shooting.The most notable mechanic is time manipulation, and you can have some pretty cool fun with it, distracting enemies with shields with a clone while you sneak behind them where they're vulnerable, piling up on them with 3 of your clones shooting a minigun at one enemy, attacking them with swords on all sides. It's pretty fun. It's also used for solving puzzles. They're not exactly brain teasers, but serve a purpose to mix things up.There are secrets to find, some items to collect, and a co-op mode that i haven't tried but that seems to be dead. Try it with a friend if you can.Also, to my great surprise seeing as how rarely games support that, even some big name developers don't seem to grasp the concept - this game supports hybrid gamepad and mouse input. Your mouse isn't disabled if you use a gamepad. This is especially good for Steam controller users, and the game is a delight to play as a result of that because you have better precission while shooting and are not limited to analog speeds. All in all, this is a great port, no issues whatsoever, and the devs actually understood how to program the game for a PC. It's amazing how big name studios tend to mess up ports, but a smaller studio makes a good job.The colors are a bit washed up, i guess that's the aesthetic they were going for, i didn't care much for that, but you can fix it as you like with SweetFX easily though so no big deal.The story starts interesting, then looses itself a bit from the middle to the end, but all in all it's ok. If you want a good story play some RPG's or something. The story here is adequate, nothing horrible, nothing impressive.Very recommended. If you have doubts, get it on sale.

												Blades of Time was a rough play for me.  There was obviously an attempt to make a solid action RPG here, but the game is bogged with problems!  - Enemies attack you through combos with no real recourse except to range them.  - Combat is "feathery", lacking any weight or strength.  - You spend a good portion of the game using the same combo attack over and over followed by a few exection skills to   finish off foes.  -The aming is loose and floaty, never feeling like you are actually aiming anything. - Sound production is horrible, giving little feedback to the world and your interactions with it.  - Interactive Objects are covered in the same grey/brown-mid-2000's color scheme making them easy to miss.-The camera has a mind of its own, often swinging around awkwardly and hiding enemies from view. - I stopped caring about the story ten minutes in.  It's cliched and typical and the stilted dialogue is entirely exposition.- Blades of Time is an attempt to blend God of War with Tomb Raider and fails to capture any of what makes either of those games great.- Enemies lack personality and originality- The jumping is quick and hard to controlIn closing, I couldn't do it.  Everything wrong with the first few minutes of the game is everything wrong period.  The camera, the controls, the uninspired world, the lazy enemy concepts, the bad combat, the terrible writing, the odd and exaggurated physics and the horrendously-bad Lara Croft impression was enough to make me put this one down for good.
